Telephone system.general assessment: fully digital system with international direct dialing
Telephone system.domestic: full range of services available; GSM wireless service available
Telephone system.international: country code - 1-649; the Americas Region Caribbean Ring System (ARCOS-1) fiber optic telecommunications submarine cable provides connectivity to South and Central America, parts of the Caribbean, and the US; satellite earth station - 1 Intelsat (Atlantic Ocean) (2011)

Broadcast media.value: no local terrestrial TV stations, broadcasts from the Bahamas can be received and multi-channel cable and satellite TV services are available; government-run radio network operates alongside private broadcasters with a total of about 15 stations (2007)

Television broadcast stations.value: 0 (broadcasts received from The Bahamas; 2 cable television networks) (2003)

Labor force - by occupation.note: about 33% in government and 20% in agriculture and fishing; significant numbers in tourism, financial, and other services

Agriculture - products.value: corn, beans, cassava (manioc, tapioca), citrus fruits; fish

Economy - overview.value: The Turks and Caicos economy is based on tourism, offshore financial services, and fishing. Most capital goods and food for domestic consumption are imported. The US is the leading source of tourists, accounting for more than three-quarters of the more than 1 million visitors that arrived in 2013. Three-quarters of the visitors came by ship. Major sources of government revenue also include fees from offshore financial activities and customs receipts.

Imports - commodities.value: food and beverages, tobacco, clothing, manufactures, construction materials

Exports - commodities.value: lobster, dried and fresh conch, conch shells

Environment - current issues.value: limited natural freshwater resources, private cisterns collect rainwater

Location.value: two island groups in the North Atlantic Ocean, southeast of The Bahamas, north of Haiti

Terrain.value: low, flat limestone; extensive marshes and mangrove swamps

Area - comparative.value: 2.5 times the size of Washington, DC

Climate.value: tropical; marine; moderated by trade winds; sunny and relatively dry

Land use.value: arable land 1.1%; permanent crops 0%; permanent pasture 0%

Military - note.value: defense is the responsibility of the UK

Disputes - international.value: have received Haitians fleeing economic and civil disorder

Illicit drugs.value: transshipment point for South American narcotics destined for the US and Europe

Political parties and leaders.value: Progressive National Party or PNP [Rufus EWING]

Legal system.value: mixed legal system of English common law and civil law

Legislative branch.description: unicameral House of Assembly (19 seats; 15 members in multi-seat constituencies and a single all-islands constituency directly elected by simple majority vote and 4 appointed by the governor on the advice of the premier and opposition party; members serve 4-year terms)
Legislative branch.elections: last held on 9 November 2012 (next to be held in 2016)
Legislative branch.election results: percent of vote - NA; seats by party - PNP 8, PDM 7

Constitution.value: several previous; latest signed 7 August 2012, effective 15 October 2012 (Turks and Caicos Constitution Order 2011) (2012)

National anthem.name: "This Land of Ours"
National anthem.note: serves as a local anthem; as a territory of the United Kingdom, "God Save the Queen" is the official anthem (see United Kingdom)

Executive branch.chief of state: Queen ELIZABETH II (since 6 February 1952); represented by Governor Peter BECKINGHAM (since 9 October 2013)
Executive branch.cabinet: Cabinet appointed by the governor from among members of the House of Assembly
Executive branch.elections/appointments: the monarch is hereditary; governor appointed by the monarch; following legislative elections, the leader of the majority party is appointed premier by the governor

Capital.name: Grand Turk (Cockburn Town)
Capital.time difference: UTC-5 (same time as Washington, DC, during Standard Time)
Capital.daylight saving time: +1hr, begins second Sunday in March; ends first Sunday in November

Flag description.value: blue with the flag of the UK in the upper hoist-side quadrant and the colonial shield centered on the outer half of the flag; the shield is yellow and displays a conch shell, a spiny lobster, and Turks Head cactus - three common elements of the islands' biota

Judicial branch.highest resident court(s): Supreme Court (consists of the chief justice and such number of other judges as determined by the governor); Court of Appeal (consists of the court president and 2 justices); note - appeals beyond the Supreme Court are heard by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council (in London)
Judicial branch.judge selection and term of office: Supreme Court and Appeals Court judges appointed by the governor in accordance with the Judicial Service Commission, a 3-member body of high level judicial officials; Supreme Court judges appointed until mandatory retirement at age 65, but can be extended to age 70; Appeals Court judge tenure determined by individual terms of appointment

Background.value: The islands were part of the UK's Jamaican colony until 1962, when they assumed the status of a separate crown colony upon Jamaica's independence. The governor of The Bahamas oversaw affairs from 1965 to 1973. With Bahamian independence, the islands received a separate governor in 1973. Although independence was agreed upon for 1982, the policy was reversed and the islands remain a British overseas territory.

Religions.value: Protestant 72.8% (Baptist 35.8%, Church of God 11.7%, Anglican 10%, Methodist 9.3%, Seventh-Day Adventist 6%), Roman Catholic 11.4%, Jehovah's Witnesses 1.8%, other 14%

Ethnic groups.value: black 87.6%, white 7.9%, mixed 2.5%, East Indian 1.3%, other 0.7% (2006)

People - note.value: destination and transit point for illegal Haitian immigrants bound for the Turks and Caicos Islands, The Bahamas, and the US
